ME: so I've really been looking at the press and the ads that are out there for other remote controllers .
ME: I s I spend a lot of time on the internet um surfing around doing the same thing .
ME: And then when I'm out um in people's houses or at meetings or anything like that , I try to notice what kind of remote controls people have ,
ME: and if it's convenient in the conversation I ask about it .
ME: And I would encourage you all to do the same .
ME: Um and my findings from this is that , you know , small is beautiful .
ME: Um people like something that really fits in their hand .
ME: Simple is beautiful .
ME: They don't want to have to squint at small print um ,
ME: they want buttons whose functions are obvious , and they want um as few buttons as possible ,
ME: and they don't care for the mode thing .
ME: They want each button to do something .
ME: And eye-catching is important .
ME: It's gotta look cute , it's gotta look appealing .
ME: Go ahead ,
ME: I'm trying to finish fast for you .
ME: Um and our preference is , as far as I'm concerned , are we got to get to the market before the competition .
ME: Ours has to be look really great and it has to come out before the others ,
ME: so that we have a leg up on time to sell it and push it before other people get out their Christmas item .
ME: And we should develop one or two features we can really dwell on in our ad campaign .
ME: If we try to tell people it has too many great features , um the consumer just gets confused and we don't get anywhere .
ME: So we've gotta narrow our selection down to li two things , I think , that we gonna say are really great about our our our new product .
ME: And I've been looking around um at what designs every year different things are popular .
ME: And in my research this year I found out that fruit and vegetable shapes are really popular .
ME: And people are tired of hard plastic and hard metal .
ME: They are more back into soft feel , spongy feeling things , things with maybe a little cloth on them .

text:
ID: So I've been looking at the components design .
ID: Um . Mostly by consulting remote control diagrams from the internet
ID: and also by incorporating design ideas from the last project meeting .
ID: Um , so we need some custom design parts , and other parts we'll just use standard .
ID: Um , I assume we'll be custom designing our case ,
ID: probably a hard plastic or some other material case , to protect the remote and the locator .
ID: And we'll need to custom desi design a circuit board ,
ID: because the circuit board has to take the button input and send it to the output so you have to design that each time .
ID: But once we come up with a design we'll send it to the circuit people and they'll just print it out .
ID: Um , standard parts include the buttons and the wheels , um the iPod-style wheel .
ID: The infrared L E D is actually gonna be included in the circuit board that comes with it .
ID: Um , we need a radio sender and receiver , those are standard .
ID: And al we also need a beeper or buzzer or other sort of noise thing for locating the remote .
ID: So we have some material options .
ID: Um , we can use rubber , plastic , wood or titanium .
ID: Um , I'd recommend against titanium
ID: because it can only be used in the flat cases and it's really heavy .
ID: Um , and the rubber case requires rubber buttons , so if we definitely want plastic buttons , we shouldn't have a rubber case .
PM: And why not wood ?
PM: And why not wood ?
ID: And ,
ID: hmm ?
ID: Uh , well we can use wood .
ID: I don't know why we'd want to .
ID: Um and also we should note that if we want an iPod-style wheel button , it's gonna require a m qu slightly more expensive chip .
ID: We can't use the minimal chip , we need the next higher grade , which is called regular .
ID: I don't think it's much more expensive , but it is more expensive .

abstract: The basic functions should include an on/off switch, buttons for channels one to nine, volume, mute and buttons for next and previous channel.
extractive: three out of four people claim m uh to find remote controls ugly .
text:
ME: Alright , I've done some research for functional requirements .
ME: Um yes .
ME: The working method um
ME: there were hundred uh uh w h one hundred people , uh how do you say uh , f watched using remote controls in the usability lab
ME: and they also uh filled out a questionnaire uh with a few questions .
ME: Uh , I've lined them up here .
ME: Uh , ask whether um common remote control looks good or not ,
ME: about willingness to spend money on remote control ,
ME: about zapping behaviour , and uh and stuff like that .
ME: I uh have found some interesting things .
ME: We do we do got a market .
ME: Um ,
ME: three out of four people claim m uh to find remote controls ugly .
ME: So if we make a trendy design , we sure have seventy fi seventy five percent of the market , which you can reach .
ME: Um , three out of four users uh zaps a lot , as I uh quoted here from the uh results .
ME: Zap buttons are used one hundred and sixty eight times per hour .
ME: That's quite a lot .
ME: Um ,
ME: relevant options are , of course , power buttons . Although , only used once per hour .
ME: Uh , channel selection , volume and buttons for text ,
ME: and the more um , yeah ,
ME: other functions , like audio settings , video settings , sound settings are not said to be very important and uh very much used .
ME: Furthermore , fifty percent says uh they only use ten percent of the buttons on a remote control .
ME: That doesn't say we got we can leave ninety percent off . But it sure um says we shouldn't make it too uh complicated .
ME: Fifty percent also claims uh to have lost a remote control very often in the room .
ME: And um an important thing here ,
ME: the most important customers uh , which is over seventy percent of our market , is in the age range of thirty six to sixty five years old .
ME: And uh elderly people , our market , are less interested in uh nice features , but more willingly to spend more money on remote controls .

abstract: The Marketing Expert made a presentation on trend watching, including trends in user requirements and trends in fashion.
extractive:
Uh so the general findings from that was uh in the market trends the most important aspect for remote controls were people want a fancy look and feel , rather than the the current functional look and feel of remote controls .
They also also want a remote control to be technologically innovative ,
and of course , as we predicted , that it should be easy to use .
Now I should point out that the first of those findings , fancy look and feel , is the most important ,
is twice as important as the second , technologically innovative ,
which is in turn twice as important as being easy to use .
um we found from our um consultants in Paris and Milan who des attended all the design and fashion fairs there , that fruit and vegetables are going to be the theme for clothes , shoes and furniture .
There also seems to be um a trend towards a spongy feel to materials ,
text:
ME: Uh so the general findings from that was uh in the market trends the most important aspect for remote controls were people want a fancy look and feel , rather than the the current functional look and feel of remote controls .
ME: They also also want a remote control to be technologically innovative ,
ME: and of course , as we predicted , that it should be easy to use .
ME: Now I should point out that the first of those findings , fancy look and feel , is the most important ,
ME: is twice as important as the second , technologically innovative ,
ME: which is in turn twice as important as being easy to use .
ME: So possibly that the feature that we put first is actually third
ME: is still important , but it's third in order of preference for the the subject group we looked at .
ME: Okay , um ,
ME: now the fashion update which relates to very personal preferences among our subject group ,
ME: um we found from our um consultants in Paris and Milan who des attended all the design and fashion fairs there , that fruit and vegetables are going to be the theme for clothes , shoes and furniture .
ME: So should we be thinking of using something like that in our remote control design too ?
PM: Yeah .
ME: There also seems to be um a trend towards a spongy feel to materials ,
ME: uh again in contrast to last year .

abstract: The Industrial Designer gave his presentation on the basic components of a remote control device, and advised the group to use plastic for the casing material instead of metal.
extractive:
and uh I found that too much metal in remote design could potentially cause interference with the ability of the remote to send commands .
And too much metal can cause remotes to behave unexpectedly by receiving false signals .
Um too much metal is used sometimes
and there's also the possibility of the remote catching on fire
just think of those lawsuits , that'd be really bad .
Therefore I suggest primarily plastic construction .
Um , components . Just some ideas that I had ,
um , energy source ,
it's kinda hip to be eco friendly
so I thought maybe we could do something with solar power with an alkaline battery backup .
Um the user interface ,
since we can't use metal
I was thinking maybe a high grade recycled plastic .
The chip , um , silicon based chip I don't really see any way around that ,
Um , the sender well I'm thinking infrared
'cause it is the industry standard ,
Uh PAL and N T S C compatible
and uh probably a two hundred foot range .
Um personal preferences ,
I really think that we should use plastic as opposed to metal ,
which adm admittedly is gonna come at the cost of a certain aesthetic value ,
Is is there a way that we can use um modern types of polymers , or mo modern types of plastics
that maybe do have some kind of aesthetic value
on the lapt on these laptops and other ones they use a a pretty nice ,
Yeah that shouldn't be a problem .

abstract: She explains the project, which is to create a new remote control for television that should be original, trendy, and user-friendly.
extractive:
What we're aiming to do is to create a new remote control for a television .
Um we want it to be something original , something trendy and also something user friendly ,
so it has to be quite intuitive that people are able to use this product .
text:
PM: So this is our project .
PM: What we're aiming to do is to create a new remote control for a television .
PM: Um we want it to be something original , something trendy and also something user friendly ,
PM: so it has to be quite intuitive that people are able to use this product .
PM: The method that we're going to use to complete the project , that has three components as such .
PM: There's the functional design of the the remote control .
PM: We're going

PM: and then come together for meetings to to work on that .
PM: Um similarly with the conceptual design ,
PM: we'll start off by working individually with our own expertise on our own laptops
PM: and then we'll bring what we've done together .
PM: Um and then the detailed design will come after that .
